name: Linux Critical Path and Desktop Environment Functionalities
description: This parent feature encompasses the critical core and desktop environment functionalities required for Linux systems, along with software development and multimedia support features. It includes critical paths for application, platform, system installation, and desktop environment functionalities, as well as features supporting KDE, GNOME, Xfce, LXDE, and server editions. Additionally, this feature incorporates software development toolkits and multimedia capabilities for GTK+, KDE, and containerized solutions with Docker and Kubernetes.

name: Database Management Systems
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide range of database management system (DBMS) solutions, including proprietary, open-source, and relational database systems designed for a variety of use cases. These systems provide tools and software for managing, querying, and storing data efficiently. Sub-features include database servers, database clients, and specific database products from different vendors such as Alibaba, Dogtag, MariaDB, PostgreSQL, and openGauss.

name: Server and Infrastructure Management
description: This parent feature encompasses all functionalities and packages required for setting up, managing, and integrating various types of servers and infrastructure systems. It includes support for backup solutions, cloud computing environments, networking and directory services, identity management, high availability clustering, and a wide range of server types such as email, FTP, web, print, application, and file storage. Additionally, it includes features for system resilience, load balancing, smart card authentication, and various tools for internet, legacy, and graphical services. This overarching feature provides comprehensive capabilities to ensure a robust, scalable, and centralized IT environment for enterprise and network management.

name: Lightweight Desktop Environments and Applications Suite
description: A comprehensive collection of lightweight desktop environments, commonly used applications, office productivity suites, multimedia support, and plugins tailored for resource-constrained systems. This parent feature brings together key features and packages for LXDE, LXQt, Xfce, and Deepin desktop environments, ensuring usability, elegance, and performance for users with low-end hardware or those seeking minimalistic desktop solutions.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Linux Development and Specialized Functionalities Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of tools, libraries, and functionalities designed to provide development environments, specialized toolkits, and essential utilities for building and running applications on Linux. This feature encompasses support for multiple programming languages, frameworks, design tools, robotics, and audio production, along with providing critical platform capabilities such as file-sharing with Windows, minimal and core installations, and build system essentials.

name: Cloud and Virtualization Management Stack
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and packages designed for managing cloud environments, virtualized infrastructure, Linux containers, and remote systems. This feature group covers all aspects of cloud and virtualization management, including bootloader tools, server utilities, hypervisor-specific packages, container management, remote interfaces, and graphical as well as headless virtualization environments. It supports major hypervisor platforms like VMware, Hyper-V, KVM, and libvirt, enabling seamless interaction with virtualized and containerized workloads. The stack also includes tools for the creation and management of system images, remote desktop connectivity, and offline image manipulation, ensuring robust and flexible infrastructure for users.

name: Software Development and Content Creation Ecosystem
description: A comprehensive ecosystem of tools, libraries, and frameworks to support software development, content creation, authoring, publishing, and platform compatibility. This feature encompasses development environments, language support for multiple programming languages, tools for technical and creative document creation, and compatibility layers to support legacy systems and cross-platform development. Additionally, it includes features to enable learning, enhance usability, and support web and desktop application development for Linux-based environments.

name: Comprehensive System Tools and Utilities Suite
description: A unified collection of tools, utilities, and frameworks designed for system administration, hardware management, network configuration, performance optimization, software development, scientific computation, debugging, security auditing, and specialized engineering workflows. This feature ensures comprehensive support for a wide range of system operations, from graphical administration tools to headless management and from general-purpose utilities to domain-specific tools for science, engineering, hardware design, and education.

name: Linux Product and Configuration Management
description: This feature encompasses the management of core packages and configuration support for various Linux product variants, ensuring compatibility and streamlined deployment. It also includes package conflict resolution for a comprehensive 'everything' installation setup across multiple repositories and product types. The feature is structured to handle both core package requirements and repository-based ostree support, while addressing potential conflicts within the Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation environments, as well as across AppStream and BaseOS repositories.

name: Graphical Desktop Environments and Components
description: A comprehensive feature encompassing various graphical desktop environments, window managers, applications, UX environments, and tools to support diverse user requirements and preferences. This parent feature includes traditional desktop environments such as GNOME and MATE, modern desktops like Budgie and Cinnamon, lightweight options like Enlightenment, tiling window managers such as Sway and i3, and compatibility with legacy systems. Additionally, it provides essential graphical system packages, accessibility tools, games, entertainment applications, and development utilities for the X Window System.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop
